course.subject: MATH
course.name: Honors Real Analysis
course.description: The MATH 2043 and 3043 is a rigorous sequence in analysis on the line and higher dimensional Euclidean spaces. Differentiation and integration in higher dimensions, implicit function and inverse function theorem, Stokes theorem, and Lebesgue measure.
course.prerequisites: Grade A- or above in MATH 2043

reviews.comment_workload:
Same as 2043 a.e.. l spent most of the time reading proofs and doing homework. Reading the proofs in FF's lecture note is time-consuming because there are too many technical proofs after midterm. (Completeness of L^p space, Egorov's Theorem, Carathéodory extension theorem, Tonelli-Fubini's Theorem, Vitali's Covering Theorem, Hardy-Littlewood Maximal Inequality, Lebesgue Differentiation Theorem, Radon-Nikodym’s Theorem).

Looking at the proofs is not enough after midterm, you have to really understand the common tricks for some of the proofs, especially for those proofs in product measure (eg. Cross-Section Method, using Monotone Class Theorem, Distributional Method).

You may also put less emphasis on the proofs and focus on the application for some of the theorems (eg. Tonelli-Fubini's Theorem, Vitali's 5-Covering Lemma, Area and Coarea Formulae, Radon-Nikodym’s Theorem).

FINALLY...I think the most disgusting thing about 3043 is that there is NO intuition behind some of the proofs. Especially for Vitali's Covering and Radon-Nikodym’s Theorem...I am literally speechless...idk how mathematicians can propose such creative and talented proofs...Maybe I have to integrate more 陰德 before enrolling into 3043 (-̩̩̩-̩̩̩-̩̩̩-̩̩̩-̩̩̩_-̩̩̩-̩̩̩-̩̩̩-̩̩̩-̩̩̩)

reviews.author: vert178
reviews.title: Fast-paced course with a wide coverage of topics
reviews.comment_content:
The course roughly divides into 3 parts
Multivariable part (2023 materials, rigorously, and Baire Category)
Measure theory (Only Lebesgue measure)
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Integration Theory (Dominated convergence, Lebesgue differentiation, Fubini-Tonelli (on R^n), Fundamental theorem of Calculus on Lebesgue integral)
Also touches a bit on Hilbert space (4061/4063) materials.

There were a lot of materials but given this is what Professor FF calls "the hardest course in HKUST undergraduate maths" and even thought of having first year PGs to take this course in place of 5011 as the Analysis foundation course, you should not expect this course to be easy. You are recommended to spend at least 5-8 hours reading and doing exercises every week. Some materials to self-study would be:

(Multivariable part)
Advanced Calculus by Loomis and Sternberg
Advanced Calculus by Fitzpatrick

(Measure and Integration)
Real Analysis by Stein and Shakarchi (official)
Measure, Integration and Real Analysis by S. Axler (most concise and clear for first-timers)
Real Analysis (4th ed.) by Royden and Fitzpatrick (approaches everything in a different way so if you got stuck with the above books you can try this)
reviews.comment_teaching: Pretty much one of the best professors you can ever encounter in HKUST. His teaching were very clear, and everything is presented precisely, with many explanations, examples and intuitions. However, Ivan's pace is quite fast so you are quite recommended to self-study beforehand; if you have read the materials before, you will get a much deeper understanding of the materials during lecture.
reviews.comment_grading:
Optimizes your grades based on a linear programming optimization scheme. It takes whatever is best out of 0-20% homework, 20%-50% midterm, and 40%-70% finals. The grade distribution is roughly 6A4B. So basically if you paid any form of consistent effort throughout the course, you should expect at least a B+/A-.

(I believe the same goes for Professor Fong too)

Midterm mean 40.9
Finals mean 43.1
Cutoff for A- is 50% total course grade and for A it is 60%
reviews.comment_workload: Fair. 4 homework sets, each take about 5 hours to 1 day to complete, and 1-3 additional hours to typeset in TeX (Latex is pretty much a requirement for Prof. FF and Prof. Ip's classes)

reviews.author: Mauricio
reviews.comment_content:
This course covered almost 6 chapters from Professor Min Yan's. Before the midterm it covers analysis on topics analogous to the first half of MATH2023. After the midterm the class took a drastic change and covered an introduction of measure theory(chapters 9 onwards).

6. Multivariable Function
8. Multivariable Differentiation
9. Measure
10. Lebesgue Integration
11. Product Measure
12. Differentiation on Measure
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Min Yan usually teaches at a fast pace and for the last chapter he covered topics even faster than usual. I personally like the way he teaches although not everyone I know is fond of it.
reviews.comment_grading: This semester the grading was extremely good, with more 15A's, 9B's and 2C's. But getting that A range still takes a considerable amount of effort, I still got a B+. Would be a lot easier to do so in the non-honors version.
reviews.comment_workload: Every week there is homework consisting of around 10~16 problems from the lecture notes. The time you take on these exercises will depend on your understanding of the topics. Professor also offers his previous exams for practice for the midterm and final.

The grading is excellent.

Grading is using: Total score = sup{λ homework + μ midterm + ν final : λ∈[0,0.2], μ∈[0,0.4], ν∈[0.4,0.7], λ + μ+ ν= 1}. to compute.

And getting a total of 75% or above for A-/A/A+ and about 50% or above for B-/B/B+.  The course will not be graded on a curve.

If you have never learned real analysis before, the workload may be quite heavy.

For me, HW always needed to use at least 4h to think and write. If you want to get the bonus, you need to use 2-3h to make LaTeX. Even though there are only four problem sets, I still think the workload is not light.

Also, it is hard to understand all the knowledge in lectures. You may need more time to really understand what he taught and do some exercises.

reviews.author: UnconMarketeers
reviews.title: An all-rounded real analysis course
reviews.comment_content:
Multivariable Calculus: Point-set topology in R^n, Continuity/differentiability of functions F: R^n -> R^m, Baire Category theorem, Implicit/Inverse function theorem...
(I read Spivak's Calculus on Manifold as reference, Baby Rudin Ch9 also covers most of the content)

Measure theory and Lebesgue Integration: Follows the flow of Stein's Real Analysis Ch1-3, including important contents like

1. The construction from outer measure (closed cube covering) to Lebesgue measure (open covering) to abstract measure (Caratheodory conditions)
2. Nonmeasurable set (Vitali set)
3. Littlewood Three Principles (Approximation of measurable set using finitely many disjoint cubes/Lusin theorem/Egorov theorem)
4. Construction of Lebesgue integration (simple functions -> functions with Bfs -> Nonnegative -> General -> Complex)
5. Interchange of limit and integration (BCT, MCT, LDCT), which are proven through the process of construction above
6. L^p Space, L^p norm (inequalities like Jensen inequality, Cauchy-Schwarz, Minkowski, Holder have already covered in homework of previous course)
7. Fubini-Tonelli's theorem
8. Lebesgue differentiation theorem
9. Vitali 3-covering lemma
10. Relation between bounded variation, absolute continuity, differentiability of F and integrability of F'
(Optional class) Axiom of choice - History and relation to analysis (used in BCT and those constructions involving equivalence class, and construction of Vitali 5-covering)

and he surprisingly included part of chapter 4 (Hilbert space) which echoes some contents in 2131. I checked that the remaining untaught part of this chapter is perfectly those involving functional analysis (bounded and continuous linear operator, Riesz representation theorem...)

UPDATE: After reading Folland and Royden's real analysis textbook in this winter I found that sticking on Stein's textbook is rather insufficient... Some content appeared in midterm and final like convergence in measure (midterm) and convergence modes (final) can be directly found in both textbooks but absent in Stein's book...
reviews.comment_teaching:
Wonderful. I can't believe that with that short period of teaching time, such an adequate amount of content is included.

One of the most appreciated things for me is that when he started a module (mul cal/measure theory/integration/FTC/Hilbert space) he will introduce the motivation for discussing them. He also sometimes briefly talked about the motivation behind the steps for each proof.

Also he (smartly and deliberately?) put some advanced but less applicable theorems like generalized Lagrange multiplier, converse of Lusin theorem, Steinhaus theorem, strong-type inequality... to homework, which motivated me to self-learn them through finishing the related problems.
reviews.comment_grading: Although I only got a B range (well, in both 2043 and 3043) given that I have already read the textbook once in summer, I found that my understanding for real analysis is still not all-rounded (I am too focused on the big picture instead of the technical stuff) and I think I deserve this grade.
reviews.comment_workload:
Although there're only 4 hws with selected problems (4 out of 10) graded, the other ungraded ones are also important because they usually include advanced theorems (see above). Some of them are also essential contents that should study to prepare for exams.


For exams, the understanding to the contents is much important than reciting them (c.f. Kin Li's analysis according to other's reviews?) because there is even an official cheatsheet for students. Also, self-learning the contents taught in the future (well if you know) also makes you advantageous in the exam because he DID test untaught stuff that was going to teach like absolute continuity (2043), Lebesgue number lemma (2043), convergence in measure (3043) in the midterms of both courses.

Studying counterexamples is also important for exams, but it seems that the emphasis on counterexamples is slightly deeper in 2043.

reviews.author: agoti
reviews.title: null set := {x \in \R: Ivan is a killer}
reviews.comment_content:
(Sorry, I came here just to make that joke in the title)

This is a continuation of MATH2043, with the following topics:
- Metric spaces and topology (continuation of Limits in R from MATH2043)
- Multivariable functions and derivative (continuation of Continuous and Differentiable functions in R from MATH2043)
- Measure Theory
- Lebesgue Integration, L^p space, Fubini's Theorem (continuation of Riemann integral from MATH2043)
- Fundamental Theorem of Calculus for Lebesgue Integrals
- Hilbert space (briefly, but still tested)

This course also expects you to have taken MATH2131 and MATH2023, although not being a prerequisite (fortunately for me who took neither)

I know too few about MATH courses to judge whether this is a lot or not, but it was definitely fun while it lasted. Probably has to do with the teaching.

Everyone else here seems to have some reference books or something, but I don't unfortunately. Probably explains why my score is that low lol
reviews.comment_teaching:
Real Good.

Like mentioned by others already, Ivan's teaching is very clear and intuitive. This is different from "very understandable" though, this course is hard after all, but he definitely puts a lot of effort in making sure students can follow his steps, such as visualizing some of the more "abstract" (this course is abstract enough) statements and proofs, like that for the Vitali's 3-Covering lemma.

He also provides a discord server for answering student inquiries and some other chit-chat(?), which helped with understanding the lesson material and homework questions a lot.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading, like MATH2043, is more lenient than normal courses.

Above mean guarantees an A- (which is not easy at all tbf), which Ivan further extended to cover 60% of the students. Quoting him from the discord server, it's a "privilege of honor course".

Exams are generally very very hard (revising the lecture materials is far from enough), but the finals provide "hint systems" that deducts some points in change for useful hints for finishing the problem.
In Hint System we trust.

At the end I got A- (didn't buy enough hints), but it is honestly surprising I got here in the first place with insufficient foundation, and close to no preparation for the course materials.
reviews.comment_workload:
Singlehandedly made my low-credit semester relatively hectic.

The workload isn't that much of an increase compared to MATH2043 (4 hw with 10 questions each), but rest assured you will need quite an amount of time to think of each question.

Especially for some questions, which are basically like "extra corollaries/theorems" very related to but not covered by the course materials, while they are really good "self-learning" materials, they usually took me the longest time to think of (and while some of them have solutions online, making sense of them is still really hard)

I did not start my assignments that late, but there are 2 hws where I had to give up sleeping on the day before deadline to finish them barely on time.

reviews.comment_content:
